brew-update.name: Update Homebrew
brew-update.note: Some packages may have breaking changes in updates. Check release notes if you rely on specific package versions for development. After running, review 'brew doctor' output for any issues and test critical command-line tools you depend on.

outcomes.description: Packages updated: All Homebrew packages updated to latest versions
Time required: 5-15 minutes depending on number of packages
Old versions removed: Cleanup removes old package versions
Doctor check: Reports any configuration issues

side_effects: Package versions change: Commands may have new options or changed behavior
Config warnings: Doctor may report minor configuration issues (usually safe to ignore)
Disk space freed: Cleanup removes old versions (500MB-2GB)
Minor disruption: Terminal commands may need reopening
what.timeline: Update Homebrew: 1-2 minutes. Upgrade packages: 3-10 minutes. Cleanup: 1-3 minutes. Doctor check: 30 seconds. Total: 5-15 minutes.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Before installing new packages (to avoid conflicts)

why.context: Homebrew packages receive security fixes, bug fixes, and new features regularly. Outdated packages have known vulnerabilities and may cause conflicts.

problems.description: Outdated packages with known security issues
Installing new packages fails due to outdated dependencies
Bugs in command-line tools that have been patched

why.title: Problems This Solves

browser-cache.name: Clear Browser Caches

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 5-20GB of disk space recovered
First-time slowdown: Initial website visits will be slightly slower (1-2 seconds) as cache rebuilds
Potential logins: May need to re-login to some websites where session cookies were cleared
Faster browsing: After cache rebuilds, browsing will feel snappier with fresh data

side_effects: Saved passwords remain intact (stored separately)
Bookmarks and history are preserved
Downloads folder is NOT affected
what.timeline: Operation completes in 30-60 seconds. Cache automatically rebuilds over next few days of normal browsing.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Monthly if you browse heavily (4+ hours/day)
When browsers feel sluggish or pages display incorrectly

why.context: Browsers cache images, videos, and scripts to speed up page loading. Over time (months), caches grow large and can become corrupted, causing display issues and wasting storage.

problems.description: Pages taking 5-10 seconds longer to load than normal
Images not loading, CSS styling broken, old content showing instead of updates
Browser caches growing to 5-20GB over months of heavy browsing

why.title: Problems This Solves

caches-cleanup.name: Clear User Caches
caches-cleanup.warning: Clears ALL user caches. Apps will need to rebuild their caches, which may cause temporary slowdowns on first launch.

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 2-20GB depending on how long since last cleanup
Apps slower initially: First app launch may take longer as cache rebuilds
Fresh state: Clears potentially corrupted cache data causing app issues
Automatic rebuild: Apps recreate caches automatically during normal use

side_effects: All ~/Library/Caches contents deleted
App settings and data NOT affected (only caches)
Some apps may need to re-download content (thumbnails, previews)
Temporary increase in CPU/network as caches rebuild
what.timeline: Operation completes in 30-60 seconds. Caches rebuild gradually over hours/days of normal use.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When disk space is critically low
When apps are misbehaving due to corrupted caches

why.context: Applications store temporary data in ~/Library/Caches to speed up operations. Over time, caches grow large and can become stale or corrupted, wasting space and causing issues.

problems.description: Caches consuming 5-20GB of disk space with old/unused data
Apps crashing or displaying incorrect content due to corrupted cache
Stale thumbnails, previews, or cached content showing outdated information

why.title: Problems This Solves

dev-cache.name: Clear Developer Caches

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 20-50GB of disk space recovered
First build slowdown: Next Xcode build will take 3-5x longer (full rebuild required)
Subsequent builds normal: After first rebuild, build times return to normal
Fixed autocomplete: Code completion will rebuild in background (5-10 minutes)

side_effects: All Swift Package Manager caches deleted (packages will re-download)
Simulator apps will need reinstalling
Project-specific settings preserved
what.timeline: Operation completes in 1-2 minutes. First rebuild takes 10-30 minutes depending on project size. Indexing completes in background over next 10-15 minutes.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Monthly for active developers (daily Xcode use)
When disk space is critically low

why.context: Xcode stores compiled code, indexes, and build artifacts in DerivedData. This grows rapidly and can cause build failures when cache becomes stale or corrupted.

problems.description: "Command failed" errors or mysterious compile failures despite clean code
Code completion freezes or shows outdated suggestions
DerivedData growing to 20-50GB, causing "disk almost full" warnings

why.title: Problems This Solves

dev-tools-cache.name: Clear Dev Tools Caches

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 500MB-5GB of disk space recovered
First install delay: Next package install will re-download needed packages
Clean slate: Fresh cache eliminates potential corruption issues
No project impact: Installed packages in node_modules, venv, etc. are NOT affected

side_effects: Global npm packages remain installed
Virtual environments remain intact
Project dependencies remain installed
what.timeline: Operation completes in 30-60 seconds. Cache rebuilds automatically during normal development.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Monthly to reclaim disk space from package caches
When package installs fail with cache corruption errors
After switching between major versions of Node, Python, Go, etc.
When investigating disk space issues in developer directories

why.context: Package managers cache downloaded packages to speed up installs. Over time, these caches accumulate old versions and unused packages, wasting disk space and potentially causing issues.

problems.description: npm, pip, Go, Cargo, and Composer caches growing to several GB with old/unused packages
problems.symptom: Disk space eaten by package caches

problems.description: Failed or corrupted packages causing npm install or pip install to fail
Old cached packages causing version conflicts or unexpected behavior

why.title: Problems This Solves

disk-repair.name: Repair Disk
disk-repair.warning: This is a repair operation. Only run when Verify Disk shows errors. If repair fails repeatedly, disk may be failing physically - consider replacement.

next_steps: If repair succeeds: Problem solved, monitor with monthly SMART checks
If repair fails: Disk may be physically failing - backup and replace
If errors return quickly: Physical disk failure likely - replace disk

outcomes.description: Repair attempt: diskutil attempts to fix detected file system errors
Time required: 15-30 minutes for boot disk repair
Success or failure: Reports whether errors were fixed or persist
May need Recovery Mode: Boot disk repair may require booting to Recovery Mode

side_effects: Requires exclusive access: Other apps may need to quit
May require restart: Boot disk repairs often need Recovery Mode
Backup recommended: Though rare, repairs can fail and cause data loss
what.timeline: Verification phase: 5-10 minutes. Repair phase: 10-20 minutes. Total: 15-30 minutes.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: ONLY after Verify Disk shows errors
When apps won't open or files are corrupted
Do NOT run preventively (unnecessary and time-consuming)

why.context: Disk errors corrupt files and cause crashes if left unfixed. First Aid (repair) attempts to fix file system issues like corrupted metadata, directory problems, or permission errors.

problems.description: Files won't open or show "file is damaged" errors
Mac crashing during file operations or boot
Applications failing to open or hanging at startup

why.title: Problems This Solves

disk-verify.name: Verify Disk

next_steps: If no errors found: Disk is healthy, no action needed
If errors found: Run Repair Disk to fix issues
If errors persist after repair: Consider disk replacement

outcomes.description: Health report: Shows if disk has file system errors or is healthy
No changes made: Read-only check, disk is NOT modified
Error details: Lists specific errors found (if any)
Actionable guidance: Tells you if Repair Disk is needed

side_effects: None - completely read-only operation
No disk modifications
Slight CPU usage during scan (10-15%)
what.timeline: Operation completes in 5-10 minutes. No background processing or rebuilding.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When files won't open or system feels slow

why.context: Disks can develop file system errors from crashes, power loss, or hardware issues. Early detection prevents data loss and system instability.

problems.description: Catching disk errors before they cause data loss
Determining if frequent crashes are disk-related
Identifying if sluggishness is due to disk errors

why.title: Problems This Solves

dns-flush.name: Flush DNS Cache

outcomes.description: Cache cleared: All DNS entries flushed immediately
Slight initial delay: First website visit adds ~50ms for DNS lookup
Automatic rebuild: Cache rebuilds normally during browsing
Fixed connections: Resolves "server not found" errors caused by stale DNS

side_effects: Brief 50ms delay on first visit to each website
No other impact on system or applications
Cache rebuilds automatically
what.timeline: Operation completes in 1-2 seconds. Cache rebuilds automatically during normal browsing.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When websites won't load but internet works
After changing DNS settings or VPN
After network changes (new WiFi, router changes)

why.context: macOS caches DNS lookups (website names to IP addresses) to speed up connections. Stale cache causes connection failures when DNS records change or after network configuration changes.

problems.description: Browsers showing "server not found" despite working internet
Can't reach websites after connecting to VPN
Problems after switching WiFi networks or changing DNS settings

why.title: Problems This Solves

disk-triage.name: Quick Disk Triage

outcomes.description: Overview report: Shows disk usage breakdown for home, Library, Caches, and Application Support
No changes made: Read-only analysis, no deletions
Top space consumers: Lists the 10-15 largest folders in each category
Instant insights: Quickly identify what's eating disk space

what.timeline: Scanning takes 30-90 seconds depending on number of files. Report generated immediately.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When you need a quick overview of disk usage
Before deciding which cleanup operations to run
When investigating sudden disk space loss
As a first step in disk maintenance

why.context: A fast diagnostic tool that shows where disk space is being used across key macOS directories, helping you decide which cleanup operations to prioritize.

problems.description: Not knowing which folders to clean first
Disk full warnings but unclear what's consuming space
Need quick visibility into ~/Library breakdown

why.title: Problems This Solves

ios-backups-report.name: iOS Backups Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: iPhone and iPad backups stored locally can consume 10-100GB of disk space. They're stored in a hidden location and are easy to forget about, especially if you've switched to iCloud backups.

problems.description: iOS backups stored in ~/Library/Application Support/MobileSync/Backup using significant space
Backups from devices you no longer own still taking up space
Multiple backups of the same device from different dates

when_to_run: When selling or trading in old devices

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-15 seconds

outcomes.description: Total size: Shows combined size of all iOS backups
Per-device breakdown: Lists each device with name, size, and last modified date
No changes made: Read-only report, no deletions

side_effects: This is a read-only report - nothing is deleted
Shows actual device names extracted from backup metadata
Provides instructions for safe cleanup via Finder

ios-backups-report.note: To delete old backups safely, use Finder → iPhone → Manage Backups, or System Settings → General → iPhone & iPad. Do NOT manually delete backup folders.

application-support-report.name: Application Support Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Application Support is one of the largest folders in ~/Library, often growing to 50-200GB. It contains app databases, caches, project files, and settings that many users don't realize exist.

problems.description: Application Support consuming 50-200GB without awareness
Apps storing large files invisibly (DAW samples, game data, cloud caches)
Data from uninstalled apps still taking up space

when_to_run: When investigating where disk space went

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 10-30 seconds depending on folder count

outcomes.description: Total size: Shows combined size of Application Support
Top 20 folders: Lists largest apps by data size
No changes made: Read-only report

side_effects: This is a read-only report - nothing is modified or deleted
Scanning large folders may take 10-30 seconds
Results help identify cleanup opportunities

application-support-report.note: ⚠️ DO NOT auto-delete Application Support folders. Many contain irreplaceable data like DAW projects, databases, game saves. To clean up: uninstall apps properly or manually review contents.

dev-artifacts-report.name: Dev Artifacts Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Developers accumulate build artifacts across many projects: node_modules (often 500MB+ each), Python venvs, build/dist/target directories. These can total 10-100GB.

problems.description: Hundreds of node_modules directories consuming 20-50GB total
Python .venv directories with duplicate packages
build/dist/target directories from old projects

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 30-120 seconds depending on filesystem size

outcomes.description: node_modules: Lists all node_modules directories with sizes
venvs: Lists all Python virtual environments
build artifacts: Lists build/dist/target directories
No changes made: Read-only report

side_effects: Scanning can take 1-2 minutes on large filesystems
Results are limited to top 20 per category
Hidden directories and Library are excluded

dev-artifacts-report.note: Before deleting any artifacts, verify the project is not active. Use 'rm -rf <path>' to clean up. Consider keeping node_modules for projects you're actively working on.

mail-size-report.name: Mail Size Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Mail.app stores all messages and attachments locally, which can grow to 10-50GB over years of email.

problems.description: ~/Library/Mail consuming 10-50GB
Downloaded attachments stored permanently
Years of archived messages taking space

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 10-30 seconds

outcomes.description: Total size: Shows Mail folder size
Breakdown: Shows mailbox sizes
No changes made: Read-only

mail-size-report.note: To clean: Mail → Mailbox → Erase Deleted Items/Junk. Delete old emails or move to archive.

messages-attachments-report.name: Messages Attachments Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: iMessage/SMS attachments (photos, videos, files) accumulate over years and can consume 5-50GB+.

problems.description: Attachments folder consuming 5-50GB+
Received videos taking most space
Thousands of images from conversations

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-15 seconds

outcomes.description: Total size: Shows Messages and Attachments sizes
File counts: Approximate image and video counts
No changes made: Read-only

messages-attachments-report.note: ⚠️ Contains personal data. To manage: Messages → Preferences → Keep Messages → set retention period.

cloudstorage-report.name: Cloud Storage Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Cloud storage providers (Dropbox, iCloud, Google Drive) cache files locally in ~/Library/CloudStorage, which can consume 50-500GB.

problems.description: Local copies of cloud files consuming significant space
Dropbox + iCloud + Google Drive all caching locally

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-30 seconds

outcomes.description: Total size: Shows combined cloud storage cache
Per-provider breakdown: Size by Dropbox, iCloud, Google Drive
No changes made: Read-only

cloudstorage-report.note: ⚠️ NEVER delete from ~/Library/CloudStorage directly. Use provider apps to make folders online-only or optimize storage.

virtualbox-report.name: VirtualBox Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: VirtualBox VMs store entire operating systems locally, typically 5-100GB each.

problems.description: ~/VirtualBox VMs consuming tens of GBs
Old VMs from past projects still taking space

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-10 seconds

outcomes.description: Total size: Shows combined VM storage
Per-VM breakdown: Size of each virtual machine
No changes made: Read-only

virtualbox-report.note: ⚠️ Do NOT manually delete VM folders. Use VirtualBox → Right-click VM → Remove → Delete all files.

large-files-report.name: Large Files Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Large files (videos, disk images, archives) accumulate and are often forgotten. A single forgotten download can consume gigabytes.

problems.description: Large files hiding in unexpected locations
DMG files, ISO images, large archives never cleaned up

when_to_run: When disk space is running low
Quarterly as part of cleanup routine

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 30-90 seconds depending on disk size

outcomes.description: Lists top 20 files over 500MB sorted by size
Excludes cloud storage, trash, and VMs
Read-only: no files modified or deleted

large-files-report.note: Review each file before deleting. Some large files (like VM disk images) may be intentional.

screenshot-folder-report.name: Screenshot Folder Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Screenshots pile up on Desktop over time, creating clutter and consuming space.

problems.description: Dozens of screenshots making it hard to find files
Screenshots from months or years ago still lingering

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-10 seconds

outcomes.description: Shows count and size of screenshots
Lists oldest screenshots for review
Read-only: no files modified

screenshot-folder-report.note: Consider changing screenshot location in System Settings → General → Screenshots

electron-apps-cache-report.name: Electron Apps Cache Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Electron apps (Slack, Discord, VS Code, Teams) aggressively cache data, often consuming 1-10GB each.

problems.description: Electron apps storing gigabytes of cache data
Cache not visible in normal Finder browsing

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-15 seconds

outcomes.description: Shows cache size for Slack, Discord, Teams, VS Code, Notion, Figma, Spotify
Provides instructions to clear each app's cache
Read-only: no caches cleared automatically

electron-apps-cache-report.note: Clear caches from within each app's settings for safest results.

battery-health-report.name: Battery Health Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: MacBook batteries degrade over time. Knowing health status helps plan for replacement.

problems.description: Degraded capacity causing reduced runtime
No easy way to check cycle count and health

when_to_run: Before selling or buying a used MacBook

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 2-3 seconds

outcomes.description: Shows battery condition (Normal, Replace Soon, etc.)
Shows cycle count and maximum capacity
Desktop Macs will show 'no battery detected'

battery-health-report.note: Apple rates MacBook batteries for approximately 1000 charge cycles.

downloads-cleanup.name: Clean Old Downloads
downloads-cleanup.warning: Permanently deletes installer files (.dmg, .zip, .pkg, .iso) older than 30 days from Downloads. Review the list before confirming.

outcomes.description: Space freed: Varies widely (1-50GB depending on download habits)
Permanent deletion: Files cannot be recovered after deletion
Only installers: Only targets .dmg, .zip, .pkg, .iso files older than 30 days
Confirmation required: Lists files before deletion, requires user approval

side_effects: Only affects top-level Downloads folder (not subfolders)
Regular files (documents, images) NOT affected
Recent installers (<30 days) preserved
May need to re-download installers if needed later
what.timeline: Operation completes in seconds. Preview mode shows what would be deleted without removing files.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Monthly to prevent Downloads folder bloat
After Downloads Report shows significant old installer files

why.context: Downloaded installers (.dmg, .zip, .pkg) often linger in Downloads after installation. These can consume significant space and are rarely needed again.

problems.description: Old installers from months-old software installations taking 10-50GB
Duplicate or outdated installer versions
Downloads folder becomes overwhelming to navigate

why.title: Problems This Solves

downloads-report.name: Downloads Report

outcomes.description: Size summary: Shows total size of Downloads folder
Largest files: Lists top 20 largest files for review
Old installers: Counts installer files older than 30 days that could be cleaned
No changes made: Read-only report, no deletions

what.timeline: Report generates in 5-15 seconds depending on number of files.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Before running Downloads Cleanup to preview what will be removed
Monthly to monitor Downloads folder growth
To identify large files that can be moved or deleted

why.context: Downloads is often a catch-all folder that grows unchecked. This report shows what's consuming space and identifies cleanup candidates.

problems.description: Downloads folder consuming unexpectedly large disk space
Need visibility before running cleanup
Forgotten large files or old installers

why.title: Problems This Solves

macos-check.name: Check macOS Updates

next_steps: If critical security updates shown: Consider installing soon
If feature updates shown: Plan maintenance window
If no updates: System is current

outcomes.description: Update list: Shows all available macOS updates with descriptions
No changes made: Read-only check, nothing is installed
Size information: Shows download size for each update
Instant result: Check completes in 5-10 seconds

what.timeline: Operation completes in 5-10 seconds. No background processing or downloads.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Weekly to check for critical security updates

why.context: Apple releases security patches, bug fixes, and feature updates regularly. Staying informed helps plan maintenance and address critical vulnerabilities.

problems.description: Knowing if critical security patches are available
Planning maintenance windows around available updates
Checking if known issues have been patched

why.title: Problems This Solves

macos-install.name: Install macOS Updates
macos-install.warning: Backup first before major updates. Use Time Machine or other backup solution. Some updates are large (5-12GB) and require significant disk space.

outcomes.description: Updates installed: All available macOS updates applied
Time required: 15-60 minutes depending on update size
Restart required: Most updates require restart
Improved security: Security vulnerabilities patched

side_effects: Restart required: Mac will restart during installation
Save work first: Close all apps and save work
App compatibility: Some apps may need updating after macOS update
Settings preserved: All settings and data remain intact
what.timeline: Download: 5-20 minutes (depends on internet speed). Installation: 10-30 minutes. Restart: 5-10 minutes. Total: 20-60 minutes.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When Check Updates shows critical security patches
During planned maintenance (not before important work)
When experiencing bugs that updates might fix

why.context: macOS updates fix critical security vulnerabilities, patch bugs, and improve stability. Delayed updates leave your Mac vulnerable to attacks.

problems.description: System exposed to known exploits without patches
Crashes, freezes, or glitches that updates resolve
Apps requiring newer macOS versions

why.title: Problems This Solves

mail-optimize.name: Optimize Mail Database
mail-optimize.note: Close Mail.app before running this operation. Mail will automatically rebuild the index when you next open it.

outcomes.description: Index rebuild: Mail rebuilds envelope index on next launch
Rebuild time: 5-30 minutes depending on mailbox size
Faster searches: Search results more accurate and faster
Improved performance: Mail opens messages faster

side_effects: Close Mail first: Mail must be quit before running
Rebuild on launch: Mail will rebuild index on next open
Temporary slowness: Mail may be slower during rebuild
CPU usage: Increased CPU usage during rebuild (10-20%)
what.timeline: Index deletion: instant. Rebuild on next Mail launch: 5-30 minutes. Rebuild happens in background (Mail remains usable).
what.title: Expected Results

why.context: Mail.app indexes emails for fast searching. Over time, the index can become fragmented or corrupted, causing slow performance and search issues.

problems.description: Messages taking 3-5 seconds to open or mark as read
Searches missing emails or showing deleted ones
Emails showing partial content or missing attachments

why.title: Problems This Solves

mas-update.name: Update App Store Apps
mas-update.note: Save work in all apps before updating. Some apps close during update and may lose unsaved work.

outcomes.description: Apps updated: All App Store apps updated to latest versions
Time required: 5-20 minutes depending on update sizes
Automatic downloads: Updates download and install automatically
Apps may reopen: Some apps require reopening to see changes

side_effects: Apps may restart: Some apps close and reopen after update
Interface changes: Updated apps may look slightly different
New features: May need to learn new features or UI changes
Settings preserved: App settings and data remain intact
what.timeline: Checking for updates: 5-10 seconds. Downloading: 2-10 minutes (depends on sizes and internet). Installing: 3-10 minutes. Total: 5-20 minutes.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: Before important work (to ensure apps are stable)
When apps are crashing or behaving strangely

why.context: App Store apps receive bug fixes, security patches, and new features through updates. Outdated apps may crash or have vulnerabilities.

problems.description: Outdated apps crashing due to unpatched bugs
New features available in updated versions
Old app versions with known security issues

why.title: Problems This Solves

messages-cache.name: Clear Messages Caches

outcomes.description: Space freed: Often multiple GB recovered immediately (depending on cache size).
Previews may regenerate over time as you browse conversations/attachments.
Chat history preserved: Does not delete your Messages database.

side_effects: May temporarily reduce preview availability until regenerated
No impact on chat content
what.timeline: Operation completes in seconds to a couple minutes depending on cache size.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When running low on disk space

why.context: Messages stores preview renderings and other cache data under ~/Library/Messages/Caches. This operation removes only cache files, not your chat database.

problems.description: Messages preview caches can grow into many gigabytes over time.
Old preview thumbnails and cache files accumulate and are rarely needed.

why.title: Problems This Solves

smart-check.name: Check SMART Status
smart-check.warning: If status shows "Failing", backup immediately and replace disk soon. "Failing" means imminent hardware failure within days/weeks.

outcomes.description: Health status: Shows "Verified" (healthy) or "Failing" (replace soon)
No changes made: Read-only check, disk is not modified
Instant result: Check completes in 1-2 seconds
Peace of mind: Confirmation of disk health or early failure warning

status_meanings: Verified: Disk is healthy, no predicted failures
Failing: Imminent hardware failure - backup immediately and replace disk
Not Supported: Some USB enclosures don't pass SMART data to macOS
what.timeline: Operation completes in 1-2 seconds. No waiting or background processing.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When disk makes unusual noises (clicking, grinding)
When Mac feels slow or files take long to open

why.context: SMART (Self-Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Technology) monitors disk health and predicts failures before they happen. Early detection allows backup before catastrophic failure.

problems.description: Disk failing without warning signs
Random crashes or file corruption due to disk issues
Disk struggling to read/write data efficiently

why.title: Problems This Solves

space-report.name: Disk Space Report

common_findings: Old projects: Forgotten code projects, video files, disk images
Duplicate files: Multiple copies of large files in different locations

outcomes.description: Detailed report: Shows largest folders and files sorted by size
Space breakdown: Categorizes usage (applications, documents, system, etc.)
No changes made: Read-only analysis, no deletions
Actionable insights: Identifies specific targets for cleanup

side_effects: Temporary CPU usage during scan (20-30%)
Brief disk activity (reading file sizes)
No modifications to disk
what.timeline: Scanning takes 2-5 minutes. Report generated immediately after scan. No background processing.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When running low on disk space
Before cleanup operations to prioritize targets
Monthly to monitor space usage trends

why.context: Shows exactly where disk space is being used by scanning all files and folders. Helps identify space hogs like old backups, cached data, or forgotten files.

problems.description: Disk full but can't find what's using space
Need to know which folders to target for cleanup
Old downloads, iOS backups, or forgotten projects consuming space

why.title: Problems This Solves

spotlight-reindex.name: Rebuild Spotlight Index
spotlight-reindex.warning: This is a heavyweight operation. Only run when absolutely necessary. Rebuild takes 1-3 hours and significantly impacts system performance. Avoid during important work.

next_steps: Let rebuild complete uninterrupted (check progress with Spotlight Status)
Keep Mac plugged in during rebuild

outcomes.description: Index deleted: Entire search index removed immediately
Rebuild started: Spotlight begins reindexing all files
Searches disabled: Search won't work until rebuild completes
Heavy CPU usage: CPU and battery usage will be high during rebuild

side_effects: Mac slower: System performance degraded during rebuild
Search disabled: Spotlight search won't work until complete
High CPU usage: 30-50% CPU usage during indexing
Battery drain: Significant battery usage on laptops
Avoid during work: Very disruptive to productivity
what.timeline: Index deletion: instant. Rebuild time: 1-3 hours for typical Mac. Longer for large drives (500GB+) or millions of files.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: ONLY when searches consistently return wrong results
When files don't appear in search but exist

why.context: Spotlight index can become corrupted, causing wrong search results or missing files. Rebuilding fixes the index by deleting and recreating it from scratch.

problems.description: Spotlight finding deleted files or missing existing ones
Spotlight returns nothing despite files existing
Search shows outdated or corrupted file information

why.title: Problems This Solves

spotlight-status.name: Check Spotlight Status

next_steps: If status is healthy: Problem is likely not Spotlight-related
If disabled: Re-enable Spotlight in System Settings
If problems persist: Consider Rebuild Spotlight Index

outcomes.description: Indexing status: Shows if Spotlight is indexing, idle, or disabled
No changes made: Read-only check, index is NOT modified
Instant result: Check completes in 1 second
Problem diagnosis: Determines if reindex is needed

status_meanings: Indexing enabled: Spotlight is active and building/maintaining index
Indexing disabled: Spotlight is turned off for this volume
Indexing in progress: Currently rebuilding index (X% complete)
Idle: Index is up-to-date, no current activity
what.timeline: Operation completes in 1 second. No waiting or background processing.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When Spotlight search returns no results
When you can't find files you know exist
After adding large amounts of data (check if indexing)

why.context: Spotlight indexes all files for instant search. Checking status helps diagnose search problems without reindexing unnecessarily.

problems.description: Spotlight returns no results for files you know exist
Determining if search problems require reindexing
Checking if Spotlight is consuming CPU/battery

why.title: Problems This Solves

thin-tm.name: Thin Time Machine Snapshots
thin-tm.warning: This is a destructive operation. Only use when absolutely necessary. macOS normally manages snapshots automatically - manual intervention should be rare.

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 5-50GB depending on snapshot age and size
Permanent deletion: Deleted snapshots cannot be restored (external backups unaffected)
Automatic rebuild: New snapshots will accumulate again (hourly backups resume)
System responsiveness: Mac will feel faster with more available space

side_effects: Loss of restore points: Cannot restore to deleted snapshot timestamps
External backups safe: Time Machine backups on external drives are NOT affected
Automatic snapshots continue: macOS will create new snapshots after deletion
what.timeline: Operation completes in 2-5 minutes. New snapshots begin accumulating within 1 hour.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: ONLY when disk is >88% full and you urgently need space
As last resort after trying other cleanup methods
Before major system updates when space is tight

why.context: Time Machine stores local snapshots on your disk for quick restores. macOS usually manages these automatically, deleting old snapshots when space runs low.

problems.description: Disk >88% full with urgent need for space
macOS throttling performance due to low disk space
Not enough space for macOS updates (20-40GB needed)

why.title: Problems This Solves

trim-caches.name: Trim User Caches

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 2-10GB of disk space recovered
Brief slowdown: First time opening apps may be 1-2 seconds slower
Automatic rebuild: Apps regenerate caches as needed (thumbnails, previews, etc.)
Fresh data: Apps will display current content without corruption

side_effects: Only deletes caches older than 30 days
Recent caches (<30 days) are preserved for performance
No impact on app functionality or user data
Photo thumbnails will regenerate when viewing folders
what.timeline: Operation completes in 2-5 minutes. Caches rebuild gradually over next few days of app usage.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When running low on disk space
When apps crash or display wrong content

why.context: Apps store temporary data (thumbnails, previews, downloads) in caches. Old caches waste disk space and can become corrupted, causing app misbehavior.

problems.description: "Startup disk almost full" warnings despite deleting files
Applications crashing due to corrupted cache data
Apps showing outdated thumbnails, previews, or cached content

why.title: Problems This Solves

trim-logs.name: Trim User Logs

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 500MB-2GB of disk space recovered
Permanent deletion: Old log files deleted (cannot be recovered)
Recent logs preserved: Logs <30 days old kept for troubleshooting
No app impact: No effect on app functionality

side_effects: Only deletes .log files older than 30 days
System logs in /var/log are NOT affected
Recent logs preserved for debugging
No impact on app settings or user data
what.timeline: Operation completes in 30-60 seconds. New logs accumulate normally during app usage.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: After resolving app issues (old diagnostic logs no longer useful)

why.context: Apps write diagnostic logs to track errors and activity. Old logs (>30 days) are rarely needed for troubleshooting and waste space.

problems.description: Old diagnostic logs consuming 500MB-2GB of storage
Old logs containing sensitive debugging information
Logs from long-resolved issues filling ~/Library/Logs

why.title: Problems This Solves

logs-cleanup.name: Clean Old Logs

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 100MB-2GB depending on logging activity
Recent logs preserved: Only removes logs older than 30 days
Troubleshooting intact: Recent logs for debugging remain available
Permanent deletion: Old logs cannot be recovered

side_effects: Only affects ~/Library/Logs (user logs)
System logs in /var/log NOT affected
Diagnostic data from >30 days ago will be lost
No impact on app functionality
what.timeline: Operation completes in 10-30 seconds.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: After resolving app issues (old debug logs no longer useful)

why.context: Applications write diagnostic logs to ~/Library/Logs. Old logs (>30 days) are rarely needed and consume space while potentially containing sensitive information.

problems.description: Log files accumulating to 500MB-2GB over time
Old logs containing crash reports and debug info
~/Library/Logs cluttered with logs from resolved issues

why.title: Problems This Solves

trash-empty.name: Empty Trash
trash-empty.warning: This PERMANENTLY deletes all items in Trash. This action cannot be undone. Review Trash contents before confirming.

outcomes.description: Space freed: Varies widely (could be MB to hundreds of GB)
Permanent deletion: Items cannot be recovered after emptying
Item count shown: Displays number of items and total size before deletion
Confirmation required: Must confirm before deletion proceeds

side_effects: All Trash contents permanently destroyed
No recovery possible without backup
Only affects your user's Trash (not other users on shared Mac)
what.timeline: Operation completes in seconds to minutes depending on number/size of items.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When you've reviewed Trash contents and confirmed nothing is needed
When disk space is critically low
After cleanup operations have moved items to Trash
Monthly after verifying no important files were accidentally trashed

why.context: Trash holds deleted files until manually emptied, consuming disk space. Items can accumulate for months without being permanently deleted.

problems.description: Trash containing GB of files from old cleanups
Deleted files still occupying disk space
problems.symptom: Low disk space despite deleting files

problems.description: Forgotten Trash contents from weeks/months ago

why.title: Problems This Solves

xcode-cleanup.name: Clear Xcode DerivedData

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 5-50GB depending on project count and complexity
Full rebuild required: Next Xcode build will take longer (full rebuild)
Build issues resolved: Clears potentially corrupted build cache
No project impact: Source code and project settings NOT affected

side_effects: DerivedData completely cleared
Next build for each project will be a full rebuild
Build times return to normal after first rebuild
Index will rebuild in background (5-10 minutes)
Simulators NOT affected (this is not simulator cleanup)
what.timeline: Operation completes in 5-30 seconds. First build after: 5-30 minutes depending on project size.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When Xcode builds fail with mysterious errors
When autocomplete stops working or shows stale suggestions
When disk space is low and you're an iOS/macOS developer

why.context: Xcode stores compiled code, indexes, and build artifacts in DerivedData. This grows rapidly with each project and can cause build failures when cache becomes stale or corrupted.

problems.description: Build failures with 'Command failed' or cryptic errors despite clean code
DerivedData growing to 20-50GB consuming significant disk space
Code completion frozen, showing wrong suggestions, or not working
Stale build artifacts causing runtime issues

why.title: Problems This Solves

wallpaper-aerials.name: Remove Aerial Wallpaper Videos

outcomes.description: Space freed: Can reclaim tens of GB immediately if Aerial videos are present.
If you keep using Aerial wallpapers, macOS may download them again later.

side_effects: Aerial wallpapers/screensavers may re-download content later
Does not affect your personal photos or files
what.timeline: Operation completes in seconds to a few minutes depending on size.
what.title: Expected Results

when_to_run: When disk space is low and Aerial videos are taking significant space

why.context: macOS can download high-resolution Aerial videos used for wallpapers/screensavers. They live at ~/Library/Application Support/com.apple.wallpaper/aerials/videos.

problems.description: Downloaded Aerial videos can consume tens of GB in the background.
These videos are large and often safe to remove when you need quick space.

why.title: Problems This Solves

disk-triage.name: Disk Triage

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: 'What's using my disk?' is the first question when space is low. This provides a quick, comprehensive answer without needing to run multiple commands.

problems.description: Need to identify which folders are consuming the most space
Don't know where to start looking for space hogs
Need to prioritize which cleanup operations to run first

when_to_run: Before any cleanup operation (to identify targets)
Weekly as part of health check

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 30-60 seconds depending on disk size

outcomes.description: Complete overview: Shows disk usage breakdown for Home, Library, Caches, and other key directories
Read-only: No files are modified or deleted
Actionable: Results help you decide which cleanup operations to run

disk-triage.note: This is a read-only operation. It scans directories using 'du' and 'df' commands and presents a ranked summary. No confirmation needed.

downloads-report.name: Downloads Report

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: The Downloads folder accumulates installers, archives, and forgotten files over time. This report helps identify what's taking space.

problems.description: Old DMGs, ZIPs, and installers sitting unused
Downloads folder is large but don't know what's in it
Need to know what's safe to delete before cleaning

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-15 seconds

outcomes.description: Size overview: Shows total Downloads folder size
Largest files: Lists top 20 files by size
Old installers: Shows DMG/ZIP/PKG files older than 30 days
Read-only: No files are deleted

downloads-report.note: This is a read-only operation. Use downloads-cleanup to actually remove old installers.

downloads-cleanup.name: Clean Downloads

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Old installers (.dmg, .zip, .pkg, .iso) in Downloads waste space and are rarely needed after installation.

problems.description: Old installers taking up 1-20GB
Downloads folder full of old files
Most installers can be re-downloaded if needed

when_to_run: When downloads-report shows significant old files

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 10-30 seconds

outcomes.description: Space freed: Removes old installers (typically 1-20GB)
Only old files: Only removes files older than 30 days
Only installers: Only targets .dmg, .zip, .pkg, .iso files

side_effects: Other file types are NOT touched
Recent files (< 30 days) are preserved
Can re-download installers from vendor websites if needed

downloads-cleanup.note: Requires confirmation before deleting. Use --preview to see what would be deleted without actually deleting.

xcode-cleanup.name: Xcode Cleanup

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Xcode stores compiled code, indexes, and build artifacts in DerivedData. This can grow to 50GB+ for active iOS developers.

problems.description: DerivedData folder consuming 5-50GB
Corrupted build cache causing mysterious build errors
Xcode autocomplete or indexing not working properly

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-15 seconds

outcomes.description: Space freed: Removes build cache (typically 5-50GB)
Slower first build: Next build will be a full rebuild
Clean state: Fixes build cache corruption issues

side_effects: Source code is NOT affected
Project files are NOT affected
Only build cache (DerivedData) is removed
Autocomplete and indexes will rebuild automatically

xcode-cleanup.note: Safe to run anytime. Xcode automatically rebuilds DerivedData on next build. This is equivalent to 'Product > Clean Build Folder' for all projects.

xcode-device-support.name: Xcode Device Support Cleanup

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Xcode caches device symbols for every iOS, watchOS, and tvOS version you've ever connected to. This can accumulate to 20-40GB over time, especially with frequent iOS updates.

problems.description: Device support folders consuming 10-40GB
Cached symbols for iOS versions no longer used
Separate caches for iOS, watchOS, and tvOS devices

when_to_run: After upgrading devices to new iOS versions
When you no longer develop for older iOS versions

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 5-15 seconds

outcomes.description: Space freed: Removes device caches (typically 10-40GB)
Re-download on next connection: Takes 2-5 minutes per device
Clean state: Only keep symbols for devices you currently use

side_effects: Source code is NOT affected
Project files are NOT affected
Xcode and simulators are NOT affected
Will download fresh symbols on next device connection (2-5 min)
Only removes cached device symbols, not your actual iOS device data

xcode-device-support.note: Safe to run periodically. Different from xcode-cleanup (DerivedData). This clears device-specific symbol caches that Xcode downloads when you connect physical iOS/watchOS/tvOS devices for debugging.

caches-cleanup.name: Clear User Caches

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: ~/Library/Caches is designed to be purgeable by the OS. It contains temporary data that apps can rebuild.

problems.description: Caches folder consuming 2-10GB
Corrupted cache causing app misbehavior
Stale cache data from uninstalled apps

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 10-30 seconds

outcomes.description: Space freed: Removes user caches (typically 2-10GB)
Slightly slower apps: First app launch may be slower as cache rebuilds
Fresh state: Clears potentially corrupted cache data

side_effects: Apps rebuild caches automatically on next launch
Preferences and settings are NOT affected
Documents and data are NOT affected
Some apps may need to re-download assets

caches-cleanup.note: Requires confirmation. This is different from trim-caches which only removes OLD cache files. This removes ALL user caches.

logs-cleanup.name: Clean Old Logs

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Log files accumulate indefinitely in ~/Library/Logs. Old logs are rarely needed for troubleshooting.

problems.description: Log files consuming 0.5-5GB
Thousands of old log files
Old logs may contain sensitive information

when_to_run: After resolving application issues (old diagnostic logs no longer needed)

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 10-30 seconds

outcomes.description: Space freed: Removes old logs (typically 0.5-5GB)
Recent preserved: Logs < 30 days are kept for troubleshooting
Privacy: Removes potentially sensitive log data

side_effects: Recent logs (< 30 days) are preserved
System logs (in /var/log) are NOT affected
No impact on app functionality

logs-cleanup.note: Only removes log files older than 30 days. Recent logs are preserved in case they're needed for troubleshooting.

trash-empty.name: Empty Trash

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: The Trash can hold GBs of 'deleted' files that still consume disk space until the Trash is emptied.

problems.description: Deleted files still using disk space
Thinking files are deleted when they're just in Trash
Deleted files still recoverable from Trash

when_to_run: When you're sure you don't need to recover any deleted files

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 1-60 seconds depending on Trash size

outcomes.description: Space freed: Permanently deletes all Trash contents
Cannot be undone: Files are permanently deleted
Immediate: Space is freed instantly

side_effects: Files CANNOT be recovered after emptying
This is equivalent to Finder > Empty Trash
All users' Trash is affected on multi-user systems

trash-empty.note: Requires confirmation. This permanently deletes all files in the Trash. Make sure you don't need to recover anything before running.

docker-prune.name: Docker Cleanup

why.title: Problems This Solves
why.context: Docker accumulates stopped containers, old images, and build cache that consume significant disk space. Active Docker developers can have 10-50GB of reclaimable space.

problems.description: Stopped containers, unused images, and build cache using 10-50GB
Old and dangling images from builds accumulating over time
Layer cache from builds growing unbounded

what.title: Expected Results
what.timeline: 10-60 seconds depending on amount to prune

outcomes.description: Space freed: Typically 5-50GB for active Docker users
Cleaner state: Removes stopped containers and dangling images
Running containers preserved: Only stopped/unused resources removed

side_effects: Running containers are NOT affected
Tagged images are NOT removed (only dangling/untagged)
Named volumes are NOT removed by default
Networks not used by running containers are removed
Subsequent builds may take longer (cache rebuilt)

docker-prune.note: Safe operation that only removes unused resources. Running containers, tagged images, and named volumes are preserved. Requires Docker to be installed and running.
